Â Does anyone have it?Thanks

comments.author: Cricktor
comments.body: Why did the OP crack the encryption in the first place when he doesn't have the wallet (not discussing moral issues)? I don't get it. Why waste time and energy as likely the vast majority of online circulating wallet.dat files are forged to scam money from greedy and/or gullible buyers.

comments.author: MikeJ_NpC
comments.created_time: June 25, 2023, 12:04:00 AMLast edit: June 25, 2023, 01:20:44 AM by MikeJ_NpC
comments.body: Just as others crack wallets... and there are lists... this one makes no difference than those which are allowed in other threads.38 chars is not a easy thing to do overall and just happened... so if its around great.. if not then oh well.. not holding my breathe on it. yes i agree 99% of them are just fake overall... not here to discuss the morality over it... just wanted to know if someone had the file granted its most likely fake due to the char count.. Pretty simple question.Â  The owner was running it for over 1 year and had lost the file hence why im asking for it.

comments.body: You cracked a password with a length of 38 characters? I just wonder whether this imaginary owner is retarded or what to search for a password for a wallet which he doesn't have? Why would you crack a hash without first having the wallet?Â  Do you have the address of the wallet? How many coins are we talking about? Is the public key known? I might have the wallet, just need the addy to check.ðŸ˜‰

comments.body: Quote from: ETFbitcoin on June 25, 2023, 10:01:50 AMQuote from: MikeJ_NpC on June 25, 2023, 12:04:00 AMyes i agree 99% of them are just fake overall... not here to discuss the morality over it... just wanted to know if someone had the file granted its most likely fake due to the char count.. comments.author: _act_
comments.body: Quote from: MikeJ_NpC on June 24, 2023, 07:38:38 PMDoes anyone know what wallet this hash goes too? $bitcoin$64$8701c2734f8cfd16b14a9d22165d7acb4275ee46a3b28e4f3c1b22900e7796d8$16$d5fbf738dd9c8922$113073$96$a51b29d430e980f3e493f0a0713f55fae91b708d07460b7856110dfda7ae85850223e32f897a61bd4e752ff1e36bdb61$66$03faf62cf99b86878abcd0321e191841428e290dffdd824942df087c3b94933794cracked it 38chars but cant locate the wallet. Â Does anyone have it?ThanksAn hash that contains bitcoin in letter andÂ  many symbol of $. Does that look like a valid hash to you? That is not a valid hash. Another thing is that you can not use transaction or transaction hash to determine the wallet it goes to. It it is hard or not possible to know the wallet an address belong too.With transaction hash, you can know about an address, but the transaction hash above is not valid.

comments.author: Cricktor
comments.body: Quote from: _act_ on June 26, 2023, 06:05:10 AM<snip>You could've at least asked Google, or your personal decent search engine, just briefly for the sequence $bitcoin$64$ and you would've seen quickly that this is the encrypted wallet.dat secret with which all sensitive data, namely the private keys, are encrypted.This has nothing to do with a Bitcoin transaction hash, public key or public address, obviously.Your can extract this "wallet.dat encryption secret" with something like Code:python bitcoin2john.py wallet.dat > wallet.hash
